questions.question: You are performing the cranial nerve examination in a patient with a stroke. You noticed aloss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. What is this sensation carried by?
questions.explanation: The taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the special visceral afferentof the facial nerve via chorda tympani nerve.The taste sensation from the hard and soft palate is also carried by the facial nerve via the greatersuperficial petrosal nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

questions.explanation: The given image shows left-sided lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy and the motor nucleus is located in the pons. It is located along with the abducens and vestibulocochlear nerve nuclei.

questions.question: 206Which of the following is false about the first genu of the facial nerve?

options.A: Contains a ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland
options.B: Gives the first branch of the facial nerve
options.C: Lies on the posterior wall of the middle ear
options.D: Between the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus and the geniculate ganglion.

questions.explanation: The 1st genu of the facial nerve lies on the medial wall of the middle ear and not posterior wall.It is formed at the geniculate ganglion when the facial nerve from the fundus of the internalacoustic meatus takes a turn posteriorly. Then the facial nerve continues as a tympanic orhorizontal segment.It homes the geniculate ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland (via greater superficial petrosalnerve). It gives off the first branch of the facial nerve.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for the 2nd genu of the facial nerve?

options.B: It gives the second branch of the facial nerve
options.C: It lies on the inferior wall of the middle ear
options.D: It is at the junction of the 3rd and 4th intratemporal segments

questions.explanation: The 2nd genu of the facial nerve lies at the junction of the 3rd and the 4th intratemporal segments, between the tympanic and the mastoid segments. The 2nd genu of the facial nerve is formed where the horizontal facial nerve takes a turn inferiorly at the junction between the medial and posterior walls of the middle ear. It continues as the vertical segment of the facial nerve behind the posterior wall of the middle ear. It does not contain a ganglion and does not give any branches. The course of the facial nerve has three parts: intracranial, intratemporal, and extracranial. The intratemporal part of the facial nerve has four segments: meatal, labyrinthine, tympanic/horizontal, and mastoid/vertical segments. Option A: The Gasserian ganglion is present in the trigeminal nerve. Option B: The temporal segment of the facial nerve ends with the 2nd genu. The nerve then passes vertically downward to form the mastoid segment. The 2nd branch of the facial nerve (nerve to stapedius) arises from this segment close to the level of the 2nd genu and not from the 2nd genu.

questions.question: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
questions.explanation: The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0mm, diameter 0.61-0.68 mm). The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of the meatus to the geniculate ganglion, where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly, forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter, and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus, edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site for congenital dehiscence of the fallopiancanal?
questions.explanation: The congenital dehiscence (absence of bony cover) of the fallopian canal of the facial nerve occursmost commonly in the tympanic or horizontal segment over the oval window.216It is the most common anomaly of the facial canal. A dehiscent nerve is prone to injury at the timeof surgery. It gets easily compressed or inflamed in mastoid and middle ear infections.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve?
questions.explanation: The frontal branch is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve. The five terminal branches of the facial nerve are: Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Mandibular, and Cervical. The extratemporal course of the facial nerve starts at the stylomastoid foramen, where it exits the temporal bone and runs anteriorly to enter the substance of the parotid gland. Here, it divides into two main terminal trunks, the temporofacial and the cervicofacial. These further divide and re-anastomose to give the five terminal branches.

questions.question: A patient with an acoustic neuroma at the cerebellopontine angle presents with a facial nerve palsy. Which of the following muscles will not be paralyzed in this case?
questions.explanation: Anterior belly of digastric is not paralyzed in facial nerve palsy. Muscles supplied by facial nerve: • Nerve to stapedius - stapedius muscle. • Posterior auricular nerve - muscles of the pinna and the occipital belly of occipitofrontalis. • Muscular branches - stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric. • Terminal branches - muscles of facial expression.

questions.question: The facial nerve is not supplied by which of the following vessels?
questions.explanation: Facial artery does not supply the facial nerveVascular Supply of facial nerve:• Anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the cerebellopontine angle• Labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in theinternal auditory canal•Superficial petrosal artery, a branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies geniculate ganglionand the adjacent region•Stylomastoid artery, a branch of the posterior auricular artery supplies the mastoid segment.

questions.question: You are an ENT resident assisting on a modified radical mastoidectomy in a patient withcholesteatoma. Which of the following landmarks will not help you to identify the facialnerve?
questions.explanation: Posterior semicircular canal is not used as a surgical landmark to identify the facial nerve.Surgical Landmarks of the facial nerve for middle ear and mastoid surgery:• Processus cochleariformis - It demarcates the geniculate ganglion which lies just anterior to it.The tympanic segment of the nerve starts at this level.• Oval window and horizontal semicircular canal - The horizontal segment of the facial nerve runsabove the oval window (stapes) and below the horizontal/lateral semicircular canal.• Short process of incus - The vertical segment of the facial nerve lies medial to the short processof incus at the level of aditus.•Pyramid - The vertical segment of the facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and the posteriortympanic sulcus.218Processus cochleariformis and its relationsGeniculateganglion-First genu offacial nerveFacial nerveMARROWProcessuscochleariformis-Tendon oftensortympani

questions.question: While performing mastoid exploration, which of the following is not useful in preventing theinjury to the facial nerve?

options.C: Drilling parallel to course of nerve209

questions.explanation: A larger burr is used to prevent facial nerve injury in the mastoid exploration and not a smallerburr.Measures to reduce facial nerve injury during mastoid exploration:• Good anatomical knowledge• Working parallel to the nerve, never at an angle.• Use the biggest burr available. Smaller burrs are more harmful.•Constant irrigation prevents thermal injury• Granulations present over the facial nerve are best left alone.• Good magnification.220
